result.execSummary:
The defendant Jerome Newell Jr was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Armed Robbery, a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.32(2).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: -Restitution set at $849.99 payable to Heather C., and $110.00 to Savannah W., to be collected by DOC from the defendant's wages and from other monies held in the defendant's inmate account; an amount or a percentage which the department determines is reasonable for restitution to victim's nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment.

-Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay the related surcharge. Defendant to pay Court costs and all applicable assessments to be collected by DOC up to 25% from defendant's funds held in the defendant's inmate account and during term of extended supervision; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment.
-Pay all supervision fees.

with credit for 829 days time served. *09-29-2017 Amended.
-Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and is eligible for the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program after 6 years.

superMiscConds.notes:
-No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause.
-No contact with Heather C., Savannah W. 
-No alcohol or illegal drugs.
-No prescription medications without a valid prescription.

-Cooperate with agent.
-Cooperate with any correctional programs recommended.
-Follow all rules of extended supervision.

-AODA assessment and any recommended treatment.
-Random urine screens.

supervisions.notes: - Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon he may no longer use or possess any firearms or body armor; also he may not vote in any election until his civil rights have been restored.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Jerome Newell Jr

Defendant Jerome Newell in court with attorney Kaitlin A Lamb.  Defendant Jerome Newell in custody.  Stephan Eduard Nolten appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Case in court for doctor's report return. There being no challenges to the report from Dr. Holcomb by the State, Defense or Defendant, the Court finds that the defendant is incompetent to proceed at this time, but if provided with appropriate treatment, is likely to become competent within 12 months or within the maximum sentence specified for the most serious offense, whichever is less.  The proceedings are suspended.  
The defendant is committed on 11-5-19 to the Department of Health and Family Services FORTHWITH. DHFS shall coordinate with the Wisconsin Resource Center regarding defendant's current medication regimen. Order of commitment for Treatment (Incompetency) signed and filed. Case adjourned to Branch 37.  Doctor's Report Return scheduled for February 3, 2020 at 08:30 am.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Jerome Newell in court with attorney Scott Franklin Anderson.  Defendant Jerome Newell in custody.  Ronald Dague appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant wants Attorney Scott Anderson removed from the case.  Court denies defendant's request.  Court will not entertain defendant's pro se motion to withdraw guilty plea.  Sentencing proceeded.  Statements heard by State, Defense and Defendant.   The Court sentenced defendant to serve a term of IMPRISONMENT in the Wisconsin State Prisons for 14 YEARS.  INITIAL CONFINEMENT of 8 YEARS and EXTENDED SUPERVISION of 6 YEARS, with credit for 865 days time served.

CONDITIONS OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION:
-Defendant is eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program and is eligible for the Wisconsin Substance Abuse Program after 6 years
-Restitution set at $849.99 payable to Heather C., and $110.00 to Savannah W., to be collected by DOC from the defendant's wages and from other monies held in the defendant's inmate account; an amount or a percentage which the department determines is reasonable for restitution to victim;s nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment 
-Defendant to pay Court costs and all applicable assessments to be collected by DOC up to 25% from defendant's funds held in the defendant's inmate account and during term of extended supervision; nonpayment penalty shall be a civil judgment
-Defendant is to provide a DNA sample and pay the related surcharge to be collected by DOC up to 25% from the defendant's funds held in the defendant's inmate account and during term of extended supervision; nonpayment penalty shall result in a civil judgment 
-No new law violations rising to the level of probable cause
-Cooperate with agent
-Cooperate with any correctional programs recommended
-Follow all rules of extended supervision
-Pay all supervision fees 
-Obtain/maintain employment  
-Obtain GED or HSED
-No contact with Heather C., Savannah W. 
-AODA assessment and any recommended treatment
-Random urine screens
-No alcohol or illegal drugs 
-No prescription medications without a valid prescription

Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon he may no longer use or possess any firearms or body armor; also he may not vote in any election until his civil rights have been restored

Defendant Jerome Newell in court with attorney Ann T. Bowe.  Defendant Jerome Newell in custody.  Francesco Mineo for Ronald Dague appeared for the State of Wisconsin. Defendant Jerome Newell in court with attorney Ann T. Bowe.  Defendant Jerome Newell in custody.  Ronald Dague appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  On motion of the State, and for reasons stated on the record, Court ordered COUNTS 2, 3 and 4 DISMISSED to be used as READ-INS on COUNt 1.  Defendant changes plea to GUILTY.  Defendant examined as to his plea, advised of his Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty. Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived his rights. Plea questionnaire received and filed. Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea. Court found defendant guilty as charged in the information and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record.  Court advised the defendant that as a convicted felon he may no longer use or possess any firearms; also he may not vote in any election until his civil rights have been restored.  Court further advised that if he is not a US citizen, deportation is possible.  Court ordered defendant REMANDED into the custody of the Sheriff's Department pending sentencing.  Sentencing hearing scheduled for December 19, 2016 at 01:30 pm.

Attorney Ann T. Bowe in court, defendant Jerome Newell not in court, in custody.  Thomas L. Potter appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Attorney Ann Bowe has a speedy trial in another court on September 14, 2016.  Court adjourns this matter.  Defense makes a Speedy Trial Demand.  Jury trial scheduled for November 28, 2016 at 10:00 am.

Defendant Jerome Newell in court with attorney James Edgar Toran.  Defendant Jerome Newell in custody.  Denis John Stingl appeared for Ron Dague for the State of Wisconsin. Court finds based on the doctors' reports defendant is competent to proceed.  Court remands the defendant.
